message_1:
What is the Floer homology of the torus knot T(3,5)?

(Note: The torus knot T(3,5) is a knot that winds three times around the central tube of a torus and five times around the longitudinal direction of the torus.)
message_2:
The Floer homology is a powerful tool in the study of low-dimensional topology, particularly in the context of knots and 3-manifolds. For knots, Heegaard Floer homology is a popular version of Floer homology, introduced by Peter Ozsváth and Zoltán Szabó.

For torus knots T(p, q), the knot Floer homology is known to be determined by the Alexander polynomial. The Alexander polynomial of a torus knot T(p, q) is given by:

Δ_T(p,q)(t) = (t^(pq) - 1) / (t - 1)

For the torus knot T(3, 5), we have:

Δ_T(3,5)(t) = (t^(3*5) - 1) / (t - 1) = (t^15 - 1) / (t - 1)

Now, to compute the knot Floer homology, we can use the formula:

HFK(T(p, q), i) = Z for i in the range -g to g, where g = (p-1)(q-1)/2

For T(3, 5), we have g = (3-1)(5-1)/2 = 4. So, we need to compute the knot Floer homology groups for i in the range -4 to 4.

The knot Floer homology groups HFK(T(3, 5), i) are isomorphic to the homology of the chain complex generated by the Alexander polynomial. In this case, the knot Floer homology groups are:

HFK(T(3, 5), -4) = Z
HFK(T(3, 5), -3) = Z
HFK(T(3, 5), -2) = Z
HFK(T(3, 5), -1) = Z
HFK(T(3, 5), 0) = Z
HFK(T(3, 5), 1) = Z
HFK(T(3, 5), 2) = Z
HFK(T(3, 5), 3) = Z
HFK(T(3, 5), 4) = Z

So, the Floer homology of the torus knot T(3, 5) is given by the above groups.
